channel.title: BUbreakingSectionTwo
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from BUbreakingSectionTwo, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: OpenAI says it’s worried about ‘doomscrolling, addiction, isolation, and … sloptimized feeds’ as it rolls out Sora social media app
item.description: The company it would “periodically poll users on their wellbeing” and give them options to adjust their feed, with a built-in bias to recommend posts ...

item.title: People are talking to this AI startup’s cartoon panda as if it’s a therapist. The CEO is nervous because there’s no suicide prevention design
item.description: Users can set up a “panic button” but Earkick wasn't designed to be a suicide prevention app, said Karin Andrea Stephan, CEO and co-founder.

item.title: Trump presides over third government shutdown, with fresh opportunity to fire thousands of workers and close down federal offices
item.description: “We don’t want it to shut down,” Trump said at the White House before the midnight deadline, but he was unable to strike a deal.

item.title: How this startup CTO went on to lead technology and AI for Thomson Reuters
item.description: Thomson Reuters has been scooping up startups to bolster the company's portfolio of tax and legal tools. That's kept CTO Joel Hron quite busy too.

item.title: After Kirk’s Death, Turning Point Vows to Go On. That May Be Easier Said Than Done.
item.description: Despite a surge in new campus chapters, there is a void left by Charlie Kirk’s murder that has implications for the entire MAGA movement.

item.title: The $400 Million Restaurant Man
item.description: Stephen Starr has become one of America’s most successful restaurateurs, making and replicating dining magic at places like Pastis and Osteria Mozza.

item.title: A Tech Expo Shows What China Can Make, but Not Who’ll Buy It All
item.description: The vast Global Digital Trade Expo in Hangzhou stood as a rebuke to U.S. efforts to hem in China’s technology. But the real competition is internal, a...

item.title: Should the Autism Spectrum Be Split Apart?
item.description: Families of people with severe autism say the repeated expansion of the diagnosis pushed them to the sidelines. A new focus on the disorder has opened...

item.title: Wealthy Southern California town sees 4 backyards fall into the ocean—but it’s not the ‘Portuguese Bend Landslide Complex’
item.description: Four backyards in Rancho Palos Verdes were damaged Saturday evening by significant soil movement from the sinking land, according to the city.

item.title: A Tech Expo Shows What China Can Make, but Not Who’ll Buy It All
item.description: The vast Global Digital Trade Expo in Hangzhou stood as a rebuke to U.S. efforts to hem in China’s technology. But the real competition is internal, a...

item.title: Internet Is Restored in Afghanistan After a Two-Day Blackout
item.description: No reason was immediately given for why service had resumed. The scope of the blackout was rare, even for a government that had drastically curtailed ...

item.title: Moscow Indicates Retaliation if Europe Uses Russian Assets for Ukraine
item.description: Amid a plan to lend $165 billion to Kyiv using Russian state assets, European officials are mindful of the possibility of blowback as they gather to d...

item.title: The Global Sumud Flotilla Is Approaching Gaza. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: Israel’s government has said it will do whatever is necessary to keep the Global Sumud Flotilla from reaching the Gaza Strip.

item.title: Gaza City Exodus Is Overwhelming Relief Efforts, Aid Agencies Say
item.description: The hundreds of thousands of Palestinians fleeing Israel’s expanded ground offensive are further straining services, aid groups say. Hospitals are ove...

item.title: Bronx Building Partially Collapses in Public Housing Complex
item.description: Fire officials said an incinerator shaft in the Alexander Avenue building had fallen in after reports of an explosion. There were no reports of injuri...
